sen.j: 亭子院（ていじのいん）は、西洞院通の西側、左京七条二坊の十三町十四町に位置した平安時代に在位した宇多天皇の譲位後の後院である。
sen.e: Located in 13th cho and 14th cho of seventh-jo and second-bo (Jo: a street in the east-west direction; bo: a street in the north-south direction) in the left side area of the Heian-kyo capital, Teiji-in was Goin Palace (the palace for a retired emperor) of the retired Emperor Uda who was an emperor in the Heian period.

Teiji-in is the palace in which Emperor Uda who reigned during the Heian period resided after his abdication located on the western side of Nishinotoin-dori Street, in 13-cho and 14-cho, 7-jo/2-bo (where a "jo" is row of sections running east-west and a "bo" is a column of sections running north-south) in Sakyo (the left (eastern) side of the city).

sen.e: Teiji-no-in is the palace in which Emperor Uda who reigned during the Heian period resided after his abdication located on the western side of Nishinotoin-dori Street, in 13-cho and 14-cho, 7-jo/2-bo (where a "jo" is row of sections running east-west and a "bo" is a column of sections running north-south) in Sakyo (the left (eastern) side of the city).

sen.j: 亭子院歌合、亭子院酒合戦など著名な文人や大宮人を召いては宴や催しが行われたことで知られる。
sen.e: It is known that banquets and other events where famous men of literature and/or omiyabito (courtiers at the Imperial Court) participated in, such as Teijiin Uta-awase (a waka poem contest at Teijiin) and Teijiin sake kassen Contest (a sake wine-drinking contest at Tenji-in), were held there.

It is known that banquets and other events such as Teijiin Uta-awase (a waka poem contest held at Teijiin) and Teijiin Sake Kassen (a sake drinking contest held at Tenji-in) in which famous men of literature and omiyabito (courtiers at the Imperial Court) would participate were held there.

It is known that banquets and other events such as Teijinoin Uta-awase (a waka poem contest held at Teijinoin) and Teijinoin Sake Kassen (a sake drinking contest held at Teiji-no-in) in which famous men of literature and omiyabito (courtiers at the Imperial Court) would participate were held there.

sen.j: 条坊制による区画名により東七条宮とも称し、宇多天皇の中宮藤原温子の御所としても知られる。
sen.e: According to the block-naming method based on the Jo-bo system, the place was also called Higashi shichijo no Miya (the palace located on the seventh-jo on the east side), and is also known as the place of FUJIWARA no Onshi, chugu (the second consort of an emperor) of Emperor Uda.

It was also called Higashi Shichijo no Miya (lit. Palace the seventh jo on the east side) according to the jo-bo system of naming sections of the city, and is also known as the palace of Emperor Uda's wife FUJIWARA no Onshi.

sen.j: 池の中に亭(亭子）を設けていたことから、亭子院と呼ぶようになった。
sen.e: Because tei (or teishi) (an arbor) was placed in the pond, the place became called Teiji-in (a palace with Teishi).
Because a tei (or teishi) (pavilion) was placed in the pond, the place became called Teiji-in.

sen.j: また宇多法皇在命中の間は、法皇自身を指す人称として、日本紀略をはじめとして著名な大宮人らの日記、歌集等に広く記されていた。
sen.e: While Cloistered Emperor Uda was alive, Teiji-in was widely used as the term for indicating the Cloistered Emperor himself as well, and many of the term appear in diaries or collections of waka poems by famous omiyabito, in addition to "Nihongi Ryaku" (Summary of Japanese Chronologies).

During the lifetime of Cloistered Emperor Uda, the word "Teiji-in" was widely used to refer to the cloistered emperor in the diaries and poetry collections written by famous courtiers, as well as in "Nihongi Ryaku" (Summary of Japanese Chronologies).

During the lifetime of Cloistered Emperor Uda, the word "Teiji-no-in" was widely used to refer to the cloistered emperor in the diaries and poetry collections written by famous courtiers, as well as in "Nihongi Ryaku" (Summary of Japanese Chronologies).

sen.j: 昌泰2年（899年）、宇多法皇が、東七条宮を後院とすべく区画内に新たな建物を加えようとした際、古井戸から不動尊像がみつかった。
sen.e: When Cloistered Emperor Uda was going to add new buildings in the premises to make Higashi shichijo no Miya his Goin Palace, a statue of Fudo-son was found in an old well.

sen.j: これは、当該の区画が古くは弘法大師空海が賜った東寺の鬼門にあたり、空海自身が発見した霊力ある石に不動尊像を掘り付け、人目に触れぬよう埋めたものだと判った。
sen.e: It was found that, because this block corresponded to the Kimon (the northeastern (unlucky) direction) of Toji-Temple Kobo-Daishi Kukai had been awarded, Kukai sculpted a Fudo-son image out of a strange power-provided stone he found and buried the image there so that it could not be seen.

sen.j: 菅原道真の死去した延喜3年（903年）8月に、「皇太夫人藤原温子、東七条宮に遷御あらせらる」という記録がある。
sen.e: The following description is recorded in August, 903, when SUGAWARA no Michizane died: FUJIWARA no Onshi, Kotaifujin (the title for the wife of a retired emperor), moved to Higashi shichijo no Miya.

sen.e: After Cloistered Emperor Uda died on September 3, 931, the place became used not as Goin Palace but as a temple.
